poem:
Juanita's Choice  

Quiet rooms and open hours,  
the choice of whom to let in—  
a sigh, relief in veins,  
solid steps on her own ground.  
But whispers rustle paper  
under doors, against walls;  
freedom's shadow stretched thin—  
roots gripping change,  
petals caught in the breeze of doubt.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘I have done nothing wrong’: Juanita quit her job at a Melbourne brothel to work from home. Now she’s being evicted When sex work became legal in Victoria, Juanita* decided to quit her job at a brothel and begin working privately from her home in Melbourne’s western suburbs. “It was a big relief,” she says. “I could set my hours, choose my clients and, most importantly, feel safe.” But within weeks, a flyer from a". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
